I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for rural electrification was included for 
2007 in the country strategy and program 2006–2010 for Bhutan.1 On 12 July 2006, the 
Government of Bhutan confirmed that it would give priority to the TA and requested the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  include  additional  TA  components  for  transmission  and 
hydropower development. Based on the clearance of the TA concept paper,2 the ADB Fact-
Finding Mission went to Bhutan on 5–19 October 2006 for field visits and discussions with the 
Government, the Bhutan Power Corporation (BPC), and other agencies. The mission and the 
Government reached an understanding on the rationale, objectives, scope, implementation 
arrangements, terms of reference, and cost estimates of the TA.3  
 
2.  The TA aims to help the Government (i) expand rural electrification, (ii) integrate an 
interregional national transmission system, and (iii) accelerate hydropower development. The 
TA is expected to prepare the loan project to achieve these three objectives in 2008. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Water is the most productive natural resource in Bhutan. The mountainous terrain and 
the network of perennially flowing rivers and streams provide an abundant source of clean and 
renewable energy. Bhutan has 26 hydropower stations that consist of 4 major hydroelectric 
power plants,4 12 mini-hydro plants, and 10 microhydro plants, with a total installed capacity of 
about 468 megawatts (MW). Because the country’s electricity generation is significantly greater 
than the maximum domestic demand of 130 MW, Bhutan is a net power exporter. 
 
4.  Of total power generated, 70% is exported to India. Power exports account for the 
largest source of Government revenue in the form of taxes and dividends from hydropower 
companies. Given the production of an additional 1,020 MW from the Tala hydropower project 
commissioned  in  July  2006,  the  power  sector  is  expected  to  account  for  over  60%  of 
Government revenue after 2007.  
 
5.  Despite  the  nation’s  net  power  surplus,  most  people  do  not  yet  have  access  to 
electricity.5 The Government aims for 100% electrification by 2020 as outlined in the Vision 
2020,  Electricity  for  All.  The  Rural  Electrification  Master  Plan  targets  increasing  the 
electrification ratio to 52.0% under the 9th Five-Year Plan and to 85.6% under the 10th Five-
Year Plan (2008–2013). Rural electrification has substantial benefits because (i) electricity is 
cheaper than kerosene for lighting, (ii) it is environment-friendly, and (iii) it has none of the 
health  hazards  associated  with  alternative  fuel  sources  such  as  kerosene  or  wood.  Rural 
electrification also makes social interventions to the poor since it helps diversify income-earning 
activities: electrically operated rice mills and flour mills increase supplementary income and jobs, 
and small business establishments sprout where electricity is available.

5  The Special Assistance for Project Formation provided by the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) in 
2006 determined that 36% of the population had access to electricity as of 2005.

2   
6.  ADB has helped Bhutan expand rural electrification through three consecutive loans 
since 1995, covering over 19,250 households. The third loan6 is ongoing and expected to be 
completed before the original closing date of 31 March 2007. During the 10th Five-Year Plan, 
the Government aims for the electrification of 24,358 more rural households. Of these, the 
Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) plans to finance 15,424 in 10 districts. To cover 
the balance of 8,934, the Government has requested ADB’s continuous assistance for “rural 
electrification IV” in eight districts,7 including remote central and eastern regions.  
 
7.  The electrification of the central and eastern regions requires connecting two national 
grid systems (Dhajay to Gelephu) in the western and eastern regions.8 In the central and 
eastern regions, power supply comes from only one major generation station, in Kurichhu (60 
MW). In the winter, the regions are supposed to import power through the grid extended to India 
to meet significant load growth caused by energy-intensive industries,9 but they cannot because 
India itself suffers from a power shortage. Connecting the two grids will bring surplus power 
from three major hydropower stations in the western region to the central and eastern regions. 
The interregional grid connection will thus (i) establish the integrated power transmission grid 
network to increase the security and reliability of nationwide power supply; (ii) provide adequate 
power to domestic and industrial costumers in the eastern and central regions; and (iii) set up 
high-speed digital information links using optic fiber ground wires, which are common to power 
supply and information and communication technology.  
 
8.  For the past decades, ADB assistance has also focused on improving the power sector’s 
efficiency. The Government has reformed the sector by unbundling the Department of Power, 
Ministry of Trade and Industry, into (i) the Department of Energy (DOE) as the Government’s 
policy and planning agency, (ii) the Bhutan Electricity Authority (BEA) as the sector regulator, 
and (iii) the Bhutan Power Corporation as the transmission and distribution company. The 
Government and ADB see the second-generation reforms as focusing on improving the capacity 
and efficiency of hydropower generation. To optimize resources and maximize their efficiency, 
the Druk Hydro Power Corporation (DHPC) is to be established in 2008 as a holding company 
to oversee the Government’s interests in hydropower companies and projects.10 
 
9.  In July 2006, the governments of Bhutan and India signed an umbrella agreement with a 
mutual obligation to develop and trade at least 5,000 MW hydropower generation by 2020. 
Accelerating the development of hydropower for its export will be of strategic significance to 
Bhutan’s economy. It will provide low-cost power to domestic and industrial customers, making 
the  sector  environmentally,  economically,  and  financially  sustainable.  Because  the 
Government’s  fiscal  capacity  for  large  infrastructure  projects  is  limited,  the  hydropower 
development strategy will leverage public and private investments through private participation 
in development projects. Such an approach is expected to accelerate hydropower development, 
restraining Government expenditures and generating income for socioeconomic development 
such as rural electrification. Given an export market in India with a critical power shortage, clean

10.  Theoretical potential hydropower in Bhutan is 30,000 MW, only about 5% of which is 
being used. Hydropower sites are mainly export-oriented and run-of-the-river types. The Power 
Sector Master Plan has prioritized hydropower development projects. To accelerate them on a 
sustainable basis, the Government requests ADB’s support to establish a policy and institutional 
framework for private participation such as public-private partnerships (PPPs) and independent 
power producers (IPPs).  
 
11.  The Dagachhu hydropower development (114 MW), which aims to export power to India, 
is proposed as a demonstration project to be financed by leveraging public and private capital in 
line with a new policy for private participation in hydropower. It will be a run-of-the-river type with 
barrages where water will be diverted to the powerhouse, and no major backwater will be 
created.  The  development  is  planned  to  be  implemented  under  the  clean  development 
mechanism as defined in the Kyoto Protocol.11 The Dagachhu project site has technical and 
physical advantages: (i) it has moderate capacity that can be financed (with a relatively simple 
financing structure); (ii) it has a grid connection matching power evacuation closely;12 (iii) its 
access roads are close to the project site; (iv) it has low sedimentation in the river, which is 
technically favorable; and (v) unlike reservoir types of projects, run-of-the river types have  small 
environmental and social impacts relative to the economic benefits. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The project preparatory TA is designed to (i) expand the nationwide power supply and 
extend electricity to remote rural households, and (ii) enhance region-wide energy efficiency and 
cross-border  economic  cooperation.  These  impacts  will  be  achieved  by  preparing  and 
strengthening comprehensive project design, feasibility assessment, and implementation plans 
for three components: (i) rural electrification IV, (ii) interregional transmission links, and (iii) 
Dagachhu hydropower development. To help the Government promote private participation in 
hydropower development, the TA will also develop a policy and institutional framework. Each TA 
component  will  be  assessed  to  be  technically,  economically,  and  financially  feasible,  and 
socially and environmentally acceptable to the Government and ADB. The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1, and the initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 
2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will have three parts: 
 
(i)  Component 1: Expansion of rural electrification. This will focus on preparing 
the electrification of 8,934 households in eight districts. In collaboration with BPC 
staff, the study will survey line routes and update technical feasibility studies, 
including the detailed project design, cost estimates, schedule, and procurement 
packages. Tariff pricing will be analyzed along with cost recovery and cross-

subsidy  among  customer  categories  and  in  the  entire  sector’s  value  chain 
process. Since BEA aims to finalize key regulations on renewable energy, tariffs, 
and licenses within 2006, policy and regulatory impacts on rural electrification will 
also be assessed.  
 
(ii)  Component 2: Integration of the interregional national transmission system. 
The missing links to be connected will be about 45 km: 30 km of 220 kilovolts (kV) 
and 15 km of 132 kV with three interconnecting substations between Dhajay 
(Tsirang) to Gelephu. The TA will review the technical requirements and cost 
estimates and formulate the project schedule and procurement packages. The 
adequacy  of  the  overall  grid  network  system  will  be  assessed  for  future 
expansion.  
 
(iii)  Component 3: Acceleration of hydropower development. The scope of work 
includes three overlapping phases: (a) the sector road map and institutional 
framework for the hydropower sector, (b) the policy framework of hydropower 
development and private participation, and (c) the preparation of a model project 
under the policy. In the first phase, the TA will focus on improving the efficiency 
of the hydropower sector by helping the Government form DHPC. In line with the 
Good  Governance  Plus  (GG+)  Exercise  of  2005,13  the  TA  will  propose  an 
institutional framework to promote private participation. In the second phase, the 
TA  will  formulate  a  policy  and  regulatory  framework  to  promote  hydropower 
development and private participation in the form of PPPs and IPPs. Using a 
consultative and learning approach in the third phase, the TA will prepare a 
financing plan for the Dagachhu hydropower development through PPPs, where 
the public sector is proactive in financial structuring with private parties. The TA 
will help the Government introduce a framework and arrangements for private 
participation  by  preparing  the  Dagachhu  hydropower  development  as  a 
showcase.  
 
14.  The TA will facilitate environment and social safeguard assessment and clearance in the 
project areas. It will include financial and economic viability assessments for each component of 
the ensuing loan project. Financing plans for each component will be assessed to ensure that 
the  borrowing  will  be  financially  sustainable.  In  particular,  the  Dagachhu  hydropower 
development  will  need  suitable  financial  arrangements  (e.g.,  ownership  options,  financial 
structuring, and modeling) to ensure the Government’s debt sustainability. The TA will support 
the communication process to prepare the optimal financing and/or guaranteeing scheme with 
public and private investors and lenders, including bilateral and multilateral banks and/or export 
credit agencies.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA’s total cost is estimated at $1,910,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $1,600,000 
equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The Government of Bhutan will finance $310,000 equivalent of local 
currency  costs  through  in-kind  contributions,  including  office  accommodation  and  facilities, 
counterpart staff, data, and other information. The detailed cost estimates and a financing plan

to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  DOE will be the Executing Agency for all TA components. BPC will be the Implementing 
Agency  for  components  1  and  2,  and  DOE,  including  a  special-purpose  vehicle  to  be 
established, will be the Implementing Agency for component 3. Before TA implementation, DOE 
will  form  a  steering  committee  chaired  by  the  director  general  of  DOE,  with  senior 
representatives from relevant ministries and agencies14 to promote project preparation and 
policy  making.  The  planning  and  coordination  head  of  DOE  will  be  the  project  director, 
overseeing day-by-day TA implementation. DOE and BPC will establish the counterpart project 
team and appoint its manager for each TA component to help the consultants liaise with other 
government ministries and agencies, local authorities, and people in the project areas, and 
obtain data and documentation from them. DOE and BPC will provide sufficient office space, 
furniture, and support facilities to the TA consultants on time.  
 
17.  The TA will require 72 person-months of consulting services (40 international and 32 
national). The study will be implemented over 14 months, from March 2007 to April 2008. The 
areas  of  expertise  required  for  the  consultants  and  the  outline  terms  of  reference  are  in 
Appendix 4 and reporting requirements are in Appendix 1. A consulting firm or consortium of 
firms will be engaged by ADB through its quality- and cost-based selection procedures in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its 
Borrowers,  and  the  TA-financed  equipment  will  be  procured  under  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines.  The  Government  requested  ADB  for  advance  contracting  to  facilitate  TA 
implementation.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
18.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $1,600,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Bhutan for 
preparing the Bhutan Power Development Project.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
 
Most people (about 85%) live in rural areas. Rural electrification is therefore key in the Government’s development 
strategy. The Government is highly committed to develop and promote rural electrification projects, which are 
expected to benefit many. The target is to bring electricity to the entire population, rural and urban, by 2020. Under the 
present Five Year Plan of the Government, about 15,000 households are expected to be electrified, raising the 
proportion of people with electricity to 52%.  
 
Access to electricity in rural areas is key to human development as well as economic growth. Electrification does not 
only mean longer productive hours. It is also expected to improve health care delivery and education. Most of all, it will 
give rural people a greater range of opportunities to improve their lives and earning capacity. It will especially improve 
the lives of women and children, reducing the incidence of respiratory diseases and increasing their time for more 
productive activities. 
 
Another immediate tangible benefit of electrification is the reduction of the use of kerosene and wood, which are 
costly. Electricity will also be brought to rural health centers, schools, and other public facilities.  
 
Rural electrification and interregional transmission links will provide a stable supply of such electricity as well as 
opportunities for commercial business and jobs in many rural areas. Benefits from power export, owing to capacity 
increased by the new run-of-the-river generation plant in Dagachhu, will contribute to the country’s economic growth, 
providing low-cost electricity to the customers including to the most vulnerable households of the poor. Regional 
development and use of clean and renewable energy will specifically benefit the poor since they are the most harmed 
by pollution and environmental degradation. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
A socioeconomic survey will provide the basis for a social impact assessment, which will include analyses of 
resettlement issues and impacts on indigenous people.  
 
The impact of delivering electricity must be evaluated not only on the basis of the beneficiaries’ ongoing activities but 
also of the opportunities that are likely to open. A poverty analysis will be prepared during the TA to better understand 
the impacts of the ensuing loan project of the final users, particularly the poor.  
 
A benefit distribution analysis of the loan project will be performed using the results of the poverty analysis. The 
number of poor and vulnerable (based on the national poverty line and food sufficiency) will be calculated and benefits 
from new electricity connections estimated based on willingness-to-pay data from the socioeconomic survey and data 
showing current electrification rates. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?   Yes   No  
An initial stakeholder analysis was conducted during the Fact-Finding Mission. Interested groups and other 
stakeholders were identified. All stakeholders will be considered during project design, especially vulnerable ones. A 
checklist for the stakeholder analysis will be prepared. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?   Yes          No 
The participation strategy will be designed during the TA to address the needs of all stakeholders. Stakeholders will be 
consulted during project design to maximize positive impacts and minimize negative ones. Issues from affected 
communities and beneficiaries will be considered during project design and implementation.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consultant  team  will  cover  eight  major  areas  of  expertise:  (i)  policy  aspects,  (ii) 
institutional aspects, (iii) engineering, (iv) economic analysis and evaluation, (v) financial analysis 
and  management,  (vi)  regulatory  and  legal  aspects,  (vii)  environmental  assessment  and 
management, and (viii) social safeguard development. The team leader will be an international 
expert in policy or finance, and the subteam leader will be an international expert in engineering. 
The consultants’ outline terms of reference will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following tasks. 
1.  Policy Aspects (international, 5 person-months; national, 3 person-months) 
 
2.  Policy specialists will help (i) develop the sector road map, including institutional policy 
actions to strengthen the hydropower sector and accelerate hydropower development; and (ii) draft 
policy and an operations manual to promote hydropower development and private participation. 
The experts will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review regulations, policies, and plans for each TA component, and incorporate 
their requirements and impacts in the project design.  
(ii)  Highlight the successes and failures or the causes and effects of public–private 
partnership (PPP) and independent power producer (IPP) projects in other countries, 
providing  case  study  analyses  and  international  best  practices,  with  detailed 
explanations of specific terms and words for learning purposes of the executing 
and/or implementing agency (EA/IA) staff. 
(iii)  Assess power sector performance and reforms, key challenges/opportunities, the 
power trade business mechanism, and private sector interests. Identify advantages 
and strategies of Bhutan in the South Asian regional market/investment environment.  
(iv)  Identify the advantages and disadvantages of private participation in the hydropower 
sector for the Government, investors, and lenders. Clarify the financial impacts on 
the Government as well as the economic and social impacts on the country.  
(v)  Group potential hydropower projects into generic categories such as domestic or 
export,  run-of-river  or  storage,  or  small  or  large  capacity.  For  each  category, 
evaluate options for ownership, structures, governance, pricing, returns, risks, and 
incentives  of  private  participation  and  recommend  options.  Assess  prerequisite 
criteria for options if a transition from the initial to the next stage is required. 
(vi)  Develop  a  strategy  for  hydropower  development  and  private  participation,  and 
formulate a time-bound sector road map for policy actions as well as a long-term 
investment plan. 
(vii)  Formulate and finalize principal policy framework for hydropower development and 
private participation in close consultation with the Government.  
(viii)  Develop criteria to evaluate, select, and prioritize projects and project developers, 
providing  clear  and  transparent  procedures.  Prepare  manuals  and  model 
documents for tendering, evaluation, procurement, memorandums of understanding, 
concessions,  and  contracts  (e.g.,  concession  agreement,  power  purchase 
agreement). 
(ix)  Promote private sector involvement and support strategic communications among 
stakeholders  such  as  government  ministries  and  agencies,  potential  investors, 
consumers, and media.

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
2.  Institutional Aspects (international, 5 person-months; national, 5 person-months) 
 
3.  Institutional specialists will help (i) form an institutional framework to promote hydropower 
development and private participation in line with directions of Good Governance Plus (GG+) and 
other directives from the Government, and (ii) incorporate Druk Hydro Power Corporation (DHPC). 
The experts will do the following: 
 
(i)  Specify the roles of existing and future hydropower companies/plants and propose 
an  institutional  framework/structure  to  accelerate  hydropower  development  and 
private participation in it.  
(ii)  Help the EA prepare strategy and institutional action plans for the overall energy 
sector in line with directions of GG+ and other Government directives.  
(iii)  Propose a structure of an apex organization to promote and manage opportunities 
for PPP and IPP projects, and define the relationships with other sector entities and 
organizations. 
(iv)  Prepare documents that establish the organizational and procedural framework for 
the apex organization and outline the requirements for staff size and qualifications. 
Specify required staff technical skills and assess training needs to achieve them. 
(v)  Help policy specialists incorporate time-bound institutional action plans in the sector 
road map and the policy for private participation. Propose measures for institutional 
capacity building and implementation plans for the apex organization and the EA to 
accelerate hydropower development.   
(x)  Provide  advisory  support  for  the  formation  and  initial  operations  of  DHPC  in 
consultation with the EA and hydropower companies as necessary. Identify priorities 
for  institutional  capacity  building  with  time-bound  action  plans,  and  propose 
measures and implementation plans for institutional capacity building for DHPC 
where applicable. 
 
3.  Engineering Aspects (international 11 person-months; national, 8 person-months) 
 
4.  Rural  electrification  engineers  (international  3.5  person-months;  national,  8.0  person-
months) will conduct route surveys and prepare detailed project design in the eight target districts. 
A  power  system  and  transmission  engineer  (international  2.5  person-months)  will  conduct 
engineering reviews for transmission lines from Dhajay to Gelephu and Dagachhu substations, and 
a hydropower engineer (international, 3.0 person-months) and a geological/geotechnical engineer 
(international, 2.0 person-months) will assess technical feasibility for the Dagachhu hydropower 
site. The experts will do the following:  
 
(i)  Review the status of ongoing and past projects for rural electrification, distribution 
and transmission systems, and hydropower development in Bhutan, and assess 
technical issues, outcomes, and lessons. 
(ii)  In  collaboration  with  Bhutan  Power  Corporation  staff,  carry  out  route  and  road 
surveys, and update desktop surveys and technical feasibility studies for the rural 
electrification and transmission lines. Determine the least-cost design for line routes 
and substations in the project sites.  
(iii)  Propose and design additional off-grid renewable energy electrification in the target 
districts as necessary.  
(iv)  Review  geological,  geotechnical,  and  hydrological  data  and  conditions  for  the 
hydropower plant site. Assess the risks and mitigation measures and formulate the 
least-cost technical design.

Appendix 4      13 
 
(v)  Assess the adequacy of associated transmission systems to be set up for the 
hydropower project in Bhutan and India, justifying the least-cost solution for meeting 
the required capacity. Carry out system analysis as necessary.  
(vi)  Assess  and  justify  the  ensuing  loan  project  scope  with  the  least-cost  method. 
Examine  and  finalize  detailed  designs,  technical  specifications,  and  the  cost 
estimates for each component to be proposed for ADB financing, taking into account 
technical standards and system planning criteria of the Bhutan Power Corporation 
and the Bhutan Electricity Authority. 
(vii)  With counterpart staff, prepare a procurement plan, including preparation of bidding 
documents for the initial stage of the ensuing loan project following ADB guidelines 
and  its  standard  format.  Provide  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction 
contracts as necessary. 
(viii)  Prepare a detailed project implementation schedule showing anticipated progress of 
work and expenditures. The schedule may be affected by seasonal conditions. 
(ix)  Assess the capacity of the EA/IA to implement the ensuing loan project. If capacity 
is  inadequate,  propose  measures  and  plans  for  capacity  building  and  project 
implementation support. 
(x)  Assess the future expansions and priorities for an overall power system for rural 
electrification,  transmission  systems,  hydropower  development  in  line  with  the 
investment plan and the sector road map.  
 
4.  Economic Analysis and Evaluation (international 5 person-months; national, 2 
person-months) 
 
5.  In accordance with the ADB’s guidelines for the Guidance of Economic Analysis (1997) and 
the Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005), an economist (international, 3 person-
months) will analyze demand and supply and the economic viability of each component of the 
ensuing loan project, and assess tariff pricing. Governance specialists (international, 2 person-
months; national, 2 person-months) will assess the Government’s fiscal conditions and impacts on 
the ensuing loan project. The experts will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review and analyze the economic viability of each component of the ensuing loan 
project. Identify all economic costs and benefits based on sensitivity analyses and 
evaluate  economic  internal  rates  of  return  for  each  component.  Analyze 
determinants and elasticity of demand for electricity and quantify economic benefits 
estimated  on  willingness-to-pay  data  (demand  and  affordability)  from  the 
socioeconomic survey as applicable.  
(ii)  Analyze the function-wise sector’s revenues and costs in relation to tariffs, cost 
recovery, and cross-subsidy among customer groups and in the power sector’s 
value-chain  process.  Determine  future  sustainable  tariff  levels  based  on  the 
analyses to support the ensuing loan project. 
(iii)  Help policy specialists update the long-term hydropower investment plan through 
analyses of the market, forecasted load growth, and changing business environment.  
(iv)  Review  and  assess  the  impacts  of  the  Government’s  fiscal  position  and  debt 
sustainability on the ensuing loan project, simulating the Government’s revenues 
(e.g., taxes, dividends, royalties), expenditures, and borrowing capacity for various 
scenarios on the financing plans, in particular non-concessional term debts, using 
the  debt  sustainability  model  that  is  consistent  with  International  Development 
Association and International Monetary Fund guidelines.  
(v)  Identify stakeholders and conduct a distribution analysis in accordance with the 
ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact in Economic Analysis for Projects

14  Appendix 4 
 
 
(2001).  Calculate  the  poverty  impact  ratio  and  undertaking  risk  and  sensitivity 
analyses.  
(vi)  Specify indicators to monitor benefits from the ensuing loan project, and establish 
procedures and provide cost estimates for benefit monitoring and evaluation in 
terms of the ADB’s Guidelines for Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation (1992). 
(vii)  Prepare a design and monitoring framework for the ensuing loan project according 
to  ADB  standards,  clearly  identifying  impacts,  outcomes,  outputs,  inputs,  and 
activities and milestones.  
 
5.  Financial Analysis and Management (international, 9 person-months) 
 
6.  A structured finance specialist (international 5 person-months) will coordinate the financing 
schemes for each component of the ensuing loan project, particularly hydropower development. 
Under his or her supervision, a financial analyst/financial management specialist (international 4 
person-months) will assess the financial viability of each project component and of each IA. The 
specialists  will  use  the  ADB’s  Financial  Management  Assessment  Questionnaire  (2005)  and 
Financial  Due  Diligence  Methodology  Note  (2005)  as  a  guide.  In  accordance  with  the  ADB 
guidelines for the Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005), the experts will do the 
following:   
 
(i)  Review and analyze the financial viability of each component of the ensuing loan 
project. Identify all risks for revenues and costs based on sensitivity analyses, and 
evaluate financial internal rates of return for each component. Include risk mitigation 
and  risk  transfer  plans  as  necessary.  Evaluate  the  financial  attractiveness  and 
availability of the ADB Asian Pacific Carbon Fund on the ensuing loan project in 
collaboration with the environment specialist. 
(ii)  Help engineers prepare the project cost estimates, including physical and price 
contingencies, and interest and charges during construction (commitment fees and 
other financing charges, if any).  
(iii)  Prepare a financing plan for each component, assuming ADB lending and any 
prospective cofinancing, including from private lenders. Help the EA/IA arrange 
counterpart funds. Simulate and evaluate optimal financial structuring and modeling 
in terms of profits, costs, and risks through all measures such as equity, loans, or an 
insurance (guarantee) mechanism from private investors and lenders, export credit 
agencies  (ECAs),  multilateral  development  banks  (MDBs),  and  bilateral  donors. 
Incorporate  a  risk  mitigation  mechanism  or  a  sufficient  security  package  as 
applicable. Consult closely with the EA/IA and the Government on the financing 
terms.  
(iv)  Collaborate with economists to simulate profits (e.g., taxes, royalties, and dividends), 
costs,  and  debts  for  each  financing  option.  Evaluate  the  Government’s  debt 
sustainability and formulate suitable financing structure. 
(v)  Review and assess the EA/IA’s financial management of corporate planning and 
budgetary control, financial and management accounting, cost accounting, internal 
control and audit system, and data processing, and assess capacity-building needs. 
(vi)  Update  or  develop  financial  projection  models  for  each  IA  to  promote  each 
component for the next 10 years. Assess their institutional financial viability with key 
performance indicators.  
(vii)  Conduct a preliminary survey of market interests and profile ideal strategic partners 
(e.g., sponsors, financial institutions, contractors, technical advisors, ECAs, MDBs, 
bilateral donors) for hydropower development projects.

Appendix 4      15 
 
(viii)  Help policy specialists prepare a draft policy and an operations manual to define 
and promote private participation in hydropower development.  
(ix)  Support  strategic  communications  with  stakeholders  in  tendering,  procurement, 
negotiation, financial arrangements, and contractual processes for the Dagachhu 
hydropower development as necessary. Assist the EA/IA in negotiations on tariff 
and/or power purchase agreements of the hydropower development as necessary. 
(x)  Conduct  asset  appraisal  and  valuation  as  necessary,  and  prepare  or  update 
DHPC’s opening balance sheets and financial projection as applicable.  
 
6.  Regulatory and Legal Aspects (international, 2.5 person-months) 
 
7.  A regulatory and legal expert will provide legal reviews on policy related documents. The 
expert will do the following:  
 
(i)  Determine any gaps in and requirements of the legal and regulatory framework in 
relation  to  private  participation  in  the  hydropower  sector.  If  any,  recommend 
additions or revisions to laws and regulations.  
(ii)  Help policy specialists formulate policy and manuals for private participation in the 
hydropower sector. 
(iii)  Help institutional specialists prepare legal and regulatory requirements (e.g., charter) 
to establish DHPC as applicable.  
(iv)  Support  the  contractual  process  with  stakeholders  in  tendering,  procurement, 
negotiation,  and  financial  arrangements  and  agreement  for  the  Dagachhu 
hydropower development as necessary. 
 
7.  Environment  Assessment  and  Management  (international 2.5 person-months; 
national, 6.0 person-months) 
 
8.  A national environment specialist will focus on rural electrification and transmissions. An 
international  environment  specialist  will  cover  all  components  of  the  ensuing  loan  project, 
particularly the hydropower development. In accordance with relevant policies and guidelines of 
the Government and ADB, in particular, Environment Policy (2002), Environmental Assessment 
Guidelines  (2003),  and  ADB’s  Operational  Manual  on  Environment  Consideration  (2006),  the 
experts will do the following:  
 
(i)  Conduct  and  report  an  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE),  summary  IEE, 
environmental impact assessment (EIA), and summary EIA as required for each 
component  of  the  ensuing  loan  project.  Pay  special  attention  to  the  project’s 
proximity to and anticipated impacts on culturally and ecologically protected areas.  
(ii)  Prepare  an  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  as  necessary.  Include 
monitoring  program  (indicators,  frequency,  and  reporting),  and  recommend 
mitigating measures, and budgets and institutional arrangements to implement them, 
and assess the activities’ environmental benefits.  
(iii)  Document and organize public consultations at least once in representative project 
sites,  and  invite  local  stakeholders  to  them.  For  environment  category-A 
components  (e.g.,  hydropower  development),  carry  out  two  public  consultations 
(once during the early stages of EIA field work, and once when the draft EIA report 
is available and before loan appraisal by ADB).  
(iv)  Work closely with EA/IA staff to ensure that the National Environment Commission 
of the Government and the Department of Forests, and other relevant agencies

16  Appendix 4 
 
 
timely clear the proposed IEE, EIA and/or EMP. Help the EA/IA finalize IEE, EIA 
and/or EMP and their summary in accordance with the ADB format.  
(v)  Help policy specialists, economists, and finance specialists incorporate the impacts 
of the clean development mechanism (CDM) in the policy framework and economic 
and investment analyses. Evaluate the options of CDM arrangements, including the 
ADB Asian Pacific Carbon Fund, on the ensuing loan project. 
  
8.  Social Safeguard Development (national, 8 person-months) 
 
9.  The  social  safeguard  development  specialist  will  prepare  a  resettlement  plan  in  full 
consultation with affected peoples and other stakeholders. The specialist will use ADB’s Handbook 
on  Resettlement  (1995),  Handbook  on  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis  (2001),  and  Gender  and 
Resettlement Checklist (2001). In accordance with relevant laws, ADB policies and operations 
manual, in particular, Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), ADB's Operations Manual F2 on 
Involuntary Resettlement (2006), Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998), and Operations Manual F3 
on Indigenous Peoples (2006), the expert will do the following: 
  
(i)  Help the EA/IA, in collaboration with engineers and environmental specialists, and 
design  the  ensuing  loan  project  to  minimize  the  resettlement  effects.  Analyze 
alternatives to minimize adverse impacts and maximize positive social effects of the 
ensuing  loan  project.  Describe  and  compare  selected  with  rejected  routes  and 
locations;  map  the  impact  corridor;  identify  stakeholders  and  their  involvement, 
through consultation, in identifying the alternatives. 
(ii)  Screen all components of the ensuing loan project and identify permanent and 
temporary socioeconomic impacts arising from land acquisition, changes in land 
use, and restrictions of access. Determine permanent and temporary socioeconomic 
impacts of diverting/altering river flow and include measures to minimize and assist 
affected land users within the river catchments.  
(iii)  Prepare a resettlement plan with full participation of stakeholders, including the 
EA/IA, that can be implemented in Bhutan and still meet ADB policy requirements. 
The plan will include  
(a)  socioeconomic profiles (e.g., local ethnic minority profiles) of the project-
affected  communities  (20%  sample  survey),  including  an  assessment  of 
indigenous peoples, in accordance with ADB guidelines;  
(b)  a full census and inventory of lost assets (permanently or a temporarily), 
indicating the scope and magnitude of likely resettlement effects, and list 
likely  losses  of  households,  agricultural  lands,  business  and  income 
opportunities, as well as affected communal assets and public buildings; 
(c)  an entitlement matrix, according to Bhutanese and ADB’s relevant policies 
and compensation procedures, listing all likely effects, such as permanent 
and of temporary land acquisition, and a study to determine the replacement 
costs of all categories of losses, with particular attention to vulnerable groups 
including indigenous peoples; 
(d)  indicative budgets for land acquisition and resettlement costs with specific 
sourcing and approval process; 
(e)  an  implementation  schedule  consistent  with  all  the  resettlement  plan 
requirements, making sure that all compensation is carried out before the 
civil works; and 
(f)  a  grievance  mechanism  and  appeal  procedures  and  mechanisms  for 
disclosing the resettlement plan to affected persons.

Appendix 4      17 
 
(iv)  Prepare and implement a public consultation and disclosure plan to ensure that the 
EA/IA have consulted all affected people and obtained their views about the ensuing 
loan  project  and  resettlement  effects,  entitlements,  schedule,  and  options  on 
compensation and assistance in a form and language they can understand.  
(v)  Review activities for local ethnic minorities and the poor in implementing power 
projects, and assess lessons, issues, and action plans. Develop an independent 
monitoring mechanism and indicators for resettlement, and ethnic minority-related 
activities. Assess the capacity of the EA/IA to plan, manage, implement, finance, 
and monitor, and prepare capacity-building measures and training workshops for 
stakeholders.  
(vi)  Collect willingness-to-pay data used for economic analysis to estimate benefits from 
new connection in conducting the socioeconomic survey. Develop a checklist for a 
stakeholder analysis. 
(vii)  Prepare a summary poverty reduction and social strategy, including a summary 
social  analysis  and  social  impact  assessment,  and  other  relevant  documents 
according to ADB format.
